questions.text: The ethmoid sinus consists of a multiple group of air cells which are grossly divided into anterior and posterior group. The CT PNS picture given below shows ethmoid air cells. What is the name of air cells shown by asterisk * sign in this picture?
questions.solution:
Detailed Explanation: The ethmoid sinus consists of anterior group of cells called anterior ethmoid and posterior group of cells called posterior ethmoids.

Haller cells: The anterior ethmoid cells present near the floor of the orbit are known as the Haller cells or infra orbital anterior ethmoids.

Clinical significance of Haller cells:

These cells can get infected and presented as orbital cellulitis.

While removing disease from Haller cells there are chances of injury to orbit during endoscopic surgery.

Option B: Onodi cells are posterior ethmoidal air cells which are in close relation with optic nerve and internal carotid artery.

Option C: The cells in the anterior group of cells are being named as bulla ethmoidalis, agger nasi.

Option D: Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest ethmoidal air cell. Agger nasi cells are anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cells which are related to frontal sinus recess.

Key Takeaway:

Ethmoidal Air Cells and Significance:

Anterior - Agger Nasi - related to Frontal Recess , Haller - Infraorbital.

Posterior - Onodi - Related to Optic Nerve and Internal Carotid Artery.

questions.text: What is the name of the part on the dorsum of nose as shown by arrow. It is the Osseo cartilaginous junction on the dorsum of nose?
questions.solution:
Detailed Explanation:

The external nose is an Osseous cartilaginous frame work which consist of:

  • Two nasal bones.
  • Lateral to the nasal bone is the frontal process of maxilla.
  • In the centre above nasal bones is the unpaired frontal bone with its two nasal processes either side of the nasal spine. The intersection of the two bones with the frontal bone above is called Nasion. (Option D)
  • The junction of the lower end of nasal bone with the lower cartilaginous part of the nose in the middle is known as Rhinion. (Option A)
  • The junction of the upper and lower lateral cartilage is known as limen nasi or limen vestibuli. It is the site of inter cartilaginous incision in rhinoplasty. (Option B)

Key Takeaway: Bony Point in Nose Summary:


Image reference: Revision rhinoplasty website.

questions.text: The marked structure on the X ray given below is?
questions.solution:
The picture shown above shows x-ray nose and PNS lateral view. In the x-ray the posterior most sinus seen is the sphenoid sinus.

Sphenoid sinus are situated in the body of the sphenoid bone.

Three type of sphenoid pneumatization exists in sphenoid sinus, they are conchal, pre seller, and seller.


Option A , B & D:

Key Takeaway: In PNS lateral view the posterior most sinus seen is the sphenoid sinus. Sphenoid sinus are situated in the body of the sphenoid bone.

Image reference: W radiology website.

questions.text: What is the name of the vessel marked by arrow in the picture given below. This vessel is also known as artery of epistaxis?
questions.solution:
Detailed Explanation: Sphenopalatine artery is a branch of maxillary artery of external carotid artery.

It enters the nasal cavity from the sphenopalatine foramen which is present 1cm behind the posterior end of middle turbinate.

From external carotid artery two branches maxillary and facial artery supply the nose.

Maxillary artery supply the palate and then enters the nose. It gives sphenopalatine and greater palatine artery. Sphenopalatine is the main artery supplying the nose.

From facial artery septal branch of superior labial artery supply nose.

Options A & D: Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery.


Key Takeaway: Sphenopalatine artery is a branch of maxillary artery of external carotid artery. It enters the nasal cavity from the sphenopalatine foramen, which is present 1 cm behind the posterior end of middle turbinate.

questions.text: Pain sensation from the ethmoid sinus is carried by which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
Option A: Supraorbital nerve for Frontal Sinus

Option B: Lacrimal nerve doesn't supply any sinuses

Option D: Infraorbital Nerve Supplies Maxillary Sinus.

Key Takeaway: Nasociliary nerve branch of V1 supplies Ethmoid and Sphenoid Sinus.

questions.text: A60-year-old female patient presented with a complaint of loss of smell, intermittent bleeding. On nasal endoscopy a mass is seen as a reddish grey, highly vascular and polypoidal. It appears to be arising from the roof of the nose. Endoscopy picture is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical findings and picture, the diagnosis appears to be Olfactory neuroblastoma.

Olfactory neuroblastoma, also known as Esthesioneuroblastoma is a rare malignant tumor. It arises from Olfactory epithelium present the roof of the nose.

It has a bimodal age occurrence between 11 to 20 and 55 to 60 years. It spreads laterally to orbit and brain superiorly.

It is a neuro endocrine tumor which may secrete hormones thus serum and urine catecholamine should be tested.

Treatment includes a combined modality which involve local resection or craniofacial resection with postoperative radiotherapy.

Option A: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma arises from the posterior part of the nose and not from the roof and it has a ulceroproliferative appearance.

Option C: Antrochoanal polyp has a very pale appearance and very less vascularity.

Option D: Angiofibroma almost exclusively occurs in young males and present with recurrent epistaxis.

Key Takeaway:

Olfactory neuroblastoma, also known as Esthesioneuroblastoma is a rare malignant Neuro endocrine tumor. It arises from Olfactory epithelium present on the roof of the nose with bimodal age presentation 11 to 20 and 55 to 60 years. Treatment includes a combined modality which involves local resection or craniofacial resection with postoperative radiotherapy.

Image reference: www.eurjrhinol.org

choices.text: Best managed by Intranasal polypectomy with snare
Caldwell Luc operation is the treatment of choice in the recurrent cases
It originates from maxillary sinus and goes to nasopharynx

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented with complain of unilateral nasal obstruction. His nasal endoscopy finding of one nostril is given. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and endoscopy the diagnosis in this case is Antrochoanal polyp.

Antrochoanal polyp is also called as Killian's polyp. It is unilateral and localized. It is seen in young patients. The main aetiology is infection.

Probe test: It Doesn't bleed. (Option B) if Bleed / Pain S/o Concha Bullosa.

It arises from the maxillary antrum and grows back towards choanae. Hence the name antro and choanal.

The main investigation required in this case is CT scan of nose and PNS. X-ray lateral view of nose and nasopharynx shows a crescent of air between the mass and pharyngeal wall it is known as Dodd's sign or crescent sign.

Management it is best managed by Functional endoscopic sinus surgery. (Option A & D)

Key Takeaway: antrochoanal polyp are Localised Unilateral and Mostly Due to Infection. X-ray - Dodd Sign & Management - FESS

Image reference: Research gate journal.

choices.text: It is a powered rotatory shaving device with continuous Suction effect
It uses ultrasonic energy to vibrate it's blade at 55,000 cycles per second
It uses a process of repeated freezing and thawing
It converts the conductive saline solution into ionized plasma layer resulting in molecular thermal dissection

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient known case of bilateral ethmoidal polyps. He was undertaken for FESS using Microdebrider device. Picture given below. What is the principle of working in this device?
questions.solution:
Key Takeaway: Microdebrider is a powered rotary shaving device with continuous Suction effect with oscillation speed Upto 30000 rpm and rotation speed Upto 70000 rpm.

Image reference: Medtube website.

questions.text: A 18-year-old male patient presented with complain of unilateral nasal obstruction. Xray of nose and nasopharynx lateral view shows presence of Dodd's sign. Picture given below. What is the most probable diagnosis based on this?
questions.solution:
Antrochoanal polyp presents as unilateral nasal mass which occur following obstruction of osteomeatal complex.

The best investigation of AC polyp is CT scan of nose and Paranasal sinus.

It shows a mass arising from maxillary antrum and extending into posterior choanae.

Ct or Xray lateral view of nose and nasopharynx will show a column of air between the mass and the pharyngeal wall. This is known as crescent sign or Dodd sign.

Options B , C & D: This sign will be absent in the mass arising from pharyngeal wall such as angiofibroma, Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and adenoid hypertrophy.

Key Takeaway: Antrochoanal polyps are Localised Unilateral and Mostly Due to Infection. X-ray - Dodd Sign & Management - FESS.

Image reference: Applied radiology website.

choices.text: These polyps mainly develop due to allergic Etiology
The surgical management is by Functional endoscopic sinus surgery.
Ct scan of nose and paranasal sinus is the main investigation
It arises from the maxillary sinus and extends towards posterior choanae

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient presented with complain of nasal obstruction and nasal discharge since 1 month. On examination bilateral multiple polyps were seen in the picture given below. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
The endoscopic picture given above is suggestive of ethmoidal polyps.

Option D: Antrochoanal polyps as the name suggests arises from the maxillary sinus and grows towards the posterior choanae.

Ethmoidal polyps are mainly allergic in Etiology. ( Option A )

They are multiple and bilateral. Mostly seen in middle age.

Bilateral polyps seen in young should be investigated for cystic fibrosis. There is genetic defect in the chloride ion transport leading to thick and inspissated secretions.

Nasal endoscopy is done for better visualization. CT scan of nose and paranasal sinus is the main investigation of choice. ( Option C )

Medical management with steroids and antihistamines is done in the Preoperative period. Surgical management includes functional endoscopic sinus surgery. It is a highly recurrent condition. Recurrence is also managed by FESS. (Option B)

Key Takeaway:


Image reference: Research gate journal.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with complain of nasal obstruction and anosmia. Her anosmia is described as merciful anosmia. Her nasal endoscopy was performed endoscopic picture is given below. All of the following are the part of treatment in this condition Except?
questions.solution:
The history and the endoscopic picture shown here is suggestive of diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.

Excessive Surgical Destruction often leads to atrophic Rhinitis So turbinectomy can't be treatment Option (Option B)

The nasal cavity can be seen filled with infected crusting.

Atrophic rhinitis is also known as ozaenae commonly seen in young females (mnemonic young operation in young females).

Clinical features include nasal obstruction despite bilateral roomy nasal cavity, very foul smelling nasal discharge. Merciful anosmia. Atrophic pharyngitis / laryngitis.

Treatment:

Medical: Alkaline douching containing Sodium chloride, Sodium biborate and Sodium bicarbonate. 25% glucose in glycerine, kemicetine, potassium iodide, estrogen spray. (Option A & D)

Surgical young's operation / Modified Young's operation preferred with 3mm opening left. ( Option C )

Key Takeaway:

Atrophic Rhinitis Treated with Alkaline Douching , Glucose in Glycerine , Kemicetine Solution and Young Operation.

Image reference: Research gate journal

choices.text: It is caused by fungus rhinosporidium
Should be managed by excision with cautery at base

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with right sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis. On examination, a mulberry mass with white dots is seen in the right nostril. Which of the Following is true about this disease?
questions.solution:
Based on the picture and clinical presentation the diagnosis is Rhinosporidiosis.

It is a protozoan disease caused by the protozoa Rhinosporidium seeberi. (Option A) It is prevalent in south India and it is caused by bathing in ponds frequented by cattle.

Clinical features: bloody nasal discharge, obstruction, red polypoidal mass.

Biopsy is the investigation of choice which shows mulberry or strawberry mass with white dots. (Option C).

Treatment is surgical excision with cauterization of the base, Dapsone post operatively. (Option D)

Key Takeaway:

Rhinosporidiosis

  • Endemic in South India (Cattle breeders, farmers).
  • Etiology: R.seeberi (Aquatic sporozoa)

O/E: Mulberry or strawberry mass with white dots, subcutaneous nodules on skin.

  • Biopsy:Sporangium with sporangiospores.
  • Rx: Wide excision + cautery + post-op dapsone.

Image reference: The new England journal of medicine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complain of woody mass in the nose since 1 month Biopsy was taken from the mass. It showed presence of granuloma containing phagocytosed bacteria called Mikulicze cells. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathology examination of Rhinoscleroma reveals presence of granuloma containing phagocytosed bacteria called Mikulicze cells.

They also show presence of eosinophilic inclusion bodies present in the plasma cells called Russell bodies.

Rhinoscleroma is caused by a gram negative bacteria called klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.

It has three stages: Atrophic stage, Granulomatous stage and cicatricial stage.

Management includes Antibiotic regimen containing streptomycin, tetracycline, rifampicin and ciprofloxacin. Systemic steroids are given to reduce fibrosis.

Surgical removal of granulation tissue with cautery or Laser. In case of cicatrisation, the airway is dilated and polythene spacers are kept for 6 weeks.

Key Takeaway:

Rhinoscleroma: 1234 Mnemonic

1 Bac - Klebsiella Rhinoscleromatis

2 bodies - Mikulicze & Russel

3 Stages - Atrophic, Granulomatous, cicatricial

4 Antibiotic- Streptomycin, Tetracycline, Rifampicin, Ciprofloxacin

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presented with complain of a brownish nodule in the skin of nasal vestibule which does not blanch on pressure. It is sometimes described as Apple jelly nodule. Picture shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lupus vulgaris is a low grade tuberculous infection. It involves the skin of nasal vestibule.

It presents with a brownish nodule which does not blanch on pressure. It is described as Apple jelly nodule.

Tuberculosis of nose is usually secondary to pulmonary TB. It involves the anterior part of nasal septum. It causes perforation in the anterior cartilaginous part.

Diagnosis is by biopsy.

Management is Anti tubercular therapy.

Key Takeaway: Lupus vulgaris is a low grade tuberculous involving skin of nasal vestibule presents with brownish nodule which do not blanch on pressure called as apple jelly nodules which are characteristic findings.

Image reference: Research gate journal.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with a complaint of bulge over tip of the nose since 3 years. Picture given below. It is also known as potato nose. What is the underlying pathology in this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is Rhinophyma.

It is the most common benign tumour of the external nose.

It is commonly seen in middle aged men with longstanding history of acne rosacea.

It is because of the hypertrophy of sebaceous glands of tip of nose.

Clinical features include cosmetic deformity known as potato nose. It can lead to difficulty in vision due to large mass sitting on nose.

Management includes excision by CO2 laser or sharp knife and skin grafting of the raw area.

Key Takeaway:

Rhinophyma / Potato Nose is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland of tip of nose. It's managed with excision by Co2 Laser.

Image reference: Brisbane skin.

choices.text: It is a case of granulomatosis with polyangiitis
It is caused by gram positive bacilli
Histopathology shows foamy macrophages with intracytoplasmic bacilli and plasma cells with inclusion bodies called Russel bodies

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with complain of nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. On examination, a granulation tissue was seen in the nasal cavity and the tip of nose. This appearance of nose is described as woody nose or Hebra nose. Picture given below. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is Rhinoscleroma.

It is a granulomatous condition caused by gram negative bacilli called Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis also known as Frisch bacilli. It is seen more common in northern parts of India. ( Option B )

Clinical features: There are three stages:

  • Atrophic stage: lots of crusting and foul smelling nasal discharge.
  • Granulomatous stage: Extensive granuloma formation leading to known as woody nose or Hebra nose.
  • Cicatricial stage: extensive fibrosis leads to stenosis or deformity of nose.

Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy. It shows granulomas with plasma cells and macrophages. The large macrophages containing phagocytosed bacteria called Miculicze cells. The eosinophilic inclusion bodies are present in the plasma cells called Russel bodies.

Management: 1) Streptomycin, tetracycline, rifampicin and ciprofloxacin are given for atleast 6 weeks till culture becomes negative. (Option D)

  • Steroids are given to reduce the fibrosis.
  • Surgery is done only in cases where nasal deformity needs to be corrected to maintain the airway.

Key Takeaway:

Rhinoscleroma: 1234 Mnemonic

1 Bac - Klebsiella Rhinoscleromatis

2 bodies - Mikulicze & Russel

3 Stages - Atrophic Granulomatous Cicastrical

4 Antibiotic- Streptomycin Tetracycline Rifampicin Ciprofloxacin

Image reference: slide share ppt.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with complain of nasal obstruction and intermittent nasal bleeding. On examination A perforation was seen in the bony part of nasal septum. Picture given below. Which of the following is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Out of all the options given above only Syphilis causes perforation in the bony part of nasal septum.

All the other causes, Like Tuberculosis, leprosy, and sarcoidosis causes perforation in cartilaginous part of nasal septum. (Options A, C & D)

Causes of septal perforation:

  • Trauma: iatrogenic, septal surgeries, septal piercing.
  • Septal abscess
  • Granulomatous condition: Being destructive therefore those involving the nose cause perforation in cartilaginous part of the nasal septum. Some, like Syphilis and Wagner's granulomatosis cause bony perforation also.
  • Nasal myiasis: maggots in nose is called nasal myiasis.
  • Rhinolith, Tumours.

Management: perforation can be closed by flap. In case of large perforation where surgery is not possible, silastic button can be worn.

Key Takeaway:

Septum Perforation Causes:

Bony - Syphilis

Cartilaginous - TB , Leprosy , Sarcoidosis

Mixed - Wegner

Image reference: ENT today website.

choices.text: Nasal glioma , The mass do not show any change when child is crying or coughs or on bilateral jugular venous compression.
Nasolabial cyst , The mass decreases in size when child cries or coughs or on bilateral jugular vein compression
Meningoencephalocele , The mass increases in size when the child cries or coughs or on bilateral jugular venous pressure
Lacrimal sac cyst , the mass do not show any change in size when child cries or coughs or on bilateral jugular venous compression

questions.text: A 2-month-old child is brought to hospital with a swelling at the root of the nose. The swelling is compressible, bluish in color, pulsatile and trans-illuminating. Clinical picture shown below, Furstenberg's test was performed which was found to be positive, what is most probable diagnosis and what is positive Furstenberg's test?
questions.solution:
The picture shown above is of Meningoencephalocele. It is a congenital deformity where a midline defect is present in the base of skull which leads to herniation of intracranial tissues like meninges alone or along with brain tissue.

Main clinical features include: subcutaneous swelling at the root of nose. It is transilluminating, bluish in color , soft pulsatile and compressible mass.

A Furstenberg's test is performed to confirm the diagnosis. If the mass increases in size when child cries or coughs or when bilateral jugular veins are compressed then it is called positive Fürstenberg's test.

Option A: Nasal glioma are also midline nasal swelling but on contrary to meningocele nasal Glioma are firm, non compressible, non pulsatile , does not transilluminate and Fürstenberg's test will be negative.

Option B & D: Nasolabial and lacrimal sac cyst doesn't show transillumination.

Key Takeaway:

Meningoencephalocele is bluish transilluminating soft pulsatile and compressible mass which can be elicited by positive Fürstenberg test.

choices.text: It is managed by excision by sub labial approach
It is of odontogenic in origin
It is an epithelial inclusion cyst
It is epithelial remnant of nasolacrimal duct

questions.text: A 16 year old patient presented with complain of soft non- tender swelling in between the upper lip and the nose. Picture given below. CT scan shows cystic lesion separated from the underlying maxillary bone. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms, the diagnosis in this case is Nasolabial cyst.

It is an epithelial inclusion cyst which is extra osseous outside the maxillary bone. (Option C)

It may arise from: epithelial remnant of the nasolacrimal duct. (Option D) Entrapped epithelium at the site of union of medial and lateral nasal process while development of nose and cheek.

Nasolabial cyst is not of odontogenic in origin it is also called non odontogenic cyst. (Option B)

They are presented as unilateral swelling in the region of the nasolabial fold raising the upper lip and anterior part of nasal floor.

Management is excision by sub- labial approach. (Option A)

Key Takeaway:

Nasolabial Cyst

  • Non Odontogenic Epithelial Inclusion Cyst
  • Nasolacrimal duct epithelium cyst at Nasolabial fold
  • Managed with sublabial approach.

choices.text: Coloboma of eye (hole in iris or choroid or retina)

questions.text: A 1 day old child presented with complain of distress and cyanosis when being quite. The child becomes normal while crying. On nasal endoscopy bilateral choanal atresia was detected. Congenital deformity of other organs was also detected. Child was diagnosed as having CHARGE syndrome. Which of the following malformations is not included in CHARGE syndrome?
questions.solution:
Choanal atresia can be associated with other malformations. The most common of which is CHARGE syndrome. Which consist of:

C: Coloboma of eye (hole in iris, choroid and retina) and cranial nerve abnormalities. (Option A)

H: Heart abnormalities (Option C)

A: Atresia of nasal choanae

R: Retarded growth and development (Option B)

G: Genital (hypogonadism, cryptorchidism) and or urological abnormalities hypospadias.(Option D)

E: Ear abnormalities and deafness.

Besides the above abnormalities other anomalies such as facial asymmetry, cleft lip, cleft palate, tracheoesophageal fistula and impaired cognitive function.

Key Takeaway:


Image reference: Eye news website.
